boardgame.name: Genpei Kassen
源平合戦
boardgame.description:
Genpei Kassen (源平合戦) is part of the 'historical' division of Bandai's 'if' series of games. It is translated as 'Genpei War'. The 'Gen' is the Chinese pronunciation of the character for Minamoto, one of the two main combatants. 'Pei' (or 'Hei) similarly refers to the Taira, so it's the 'Minamoto-Taira War'. A strategic simulation of the 1180-1185 conflict in Japan involving the Minamoto and Taira warrior houses, it reflects the fact that fighting was not done strictly along 'clan' lines by including as other factions the Kiso (a branch of the Minamoto), the Fujiwara, and the Imperial Family. The war is still a popular subject in Japan today, being immortalized by period literature such as the Heike Monogatari ('Tale of the Heike') and live performances by blind biwa (lute) players.

The game is designed for 2-4 players taking the part of one of the four main combatants-the Taira (SW Japan), Kiso (a Minamoto branch, central Japan), Minamoto (SE Japan), and Fujiwara (N Japan). There are rules for a 5th player to operate abstractly as the Insei (retired Emperor) Go-Shirakawa, meddling with the plans of the four warrior houses. There are several different scenarios involving different numbers of players and levels of conquest. Gameplay features area movement of generic land and naval forces. Armies are generic and all have the same value, and are boosted by the values of leaders accompanying them. None of the leaders are named but each has a different skill level (if you're familiar with the history, it's easy to figure out the names that go with each leader counter). Naval warfare and sea movement of troops is somewhat abstract and confined to the southern areas of the map. Cardplay has a big effect on gameplay as cards can lead to possession of the Emperor, abundant crops, famine (denying victory points), access to independent naval forces, and other events. Victory is determined by both provinces held each turn (each province is worth a varying number of points) and enemy units destroyed.

Starting positions for the game are somewhat historically inaccurate; this was done for play balance as the Kiso are facing a two front war with the other combatants initially only having one. Factions are differentiated by their leader and naval pools. The Fujiwara have no navy, three overpoweringly wealthy provinces, and have the strongest leader in the game (and an extremely strong sub-leader). The Kiso have a middling leader, no navy, 23 relatively poor provinces, and a small pool of back up leaders. The Minamoto have a solid and large leadership pool but no navy and start with 14 provinces worth a moderate amount. The Taira have the misfortune of having an excellent leader being a subordinate of the worst leader in the game, but start off with naval forces and 20 moderately valuable provinces. There are also 3 neutral provinces that can be invaded during the game. Overall, the game has a good feel for the war it seeks to recreate and the difficulties faced by each faction.

boardgame.name: Hammered: The Shady Rogue Expansion
boardgame.description:
This is an expansion for the game Hammered where you play as a group of dwarves on a pub-crawl. This expansion adds a shady underground style theme to the game with a new character, a new tavern and a number of event cards that give the core game a sense that there is a seedy underbelly to these quaint taverns!

The game-play is the same however the expansion adds some additional rules by giving the new character a perk, the new tavern a house rule and a couple of cards that allow other players to acquire the new perk as well. This particular perk allows players to get gold even when they lose wagers and to pay less for drinks in the new tavern, everyone else has to pay extortionate prices!

boardgame.name: Hammered: The Alchemist's Mark Expansion
boardgame.description:
This is an expansion for the game 'Hammered' where you play as a group of dwarves on a pub-crawl. This expansion adds a magical theme to the core game with a new character, new tavern and wizard themed event cards.

The game plays the same however the addition of this expansion throws in some new rules. The new character has a perk, the new tavern has a house rule and there are a couple of cards that allow other players to acquire the perk as well. The tavern's house rule makes gold lost or spent inside the tavern turn into other commodities and the perk allows players to spend gold in order to make other players forfeit! There is also an additional rule that only comes into play if the card is drawn which makes the winner of the game perform a challenge before they can be crowned victorious!

boardgame.name: Dem Gems
boardgame.description:
Dem Gems is a quick play micro game and the theme of Dem Gems is rather abstract, you're collecting gems in a stoney looking labyrinth as a small coloured cylinder.... Basically you are there to collect as many gems as possible in an ever changing maze while you try to avoid holes, bombs and other players.

The cards are narrow domino cards which are first shuffled and then 8 of them are laid out face up to make a 4 x 4 square board. The remaining cards are then dealt out equally face down to the players, any remaining cards are put to one side. Each player puts their piece at a corner (not on the board yet) and rolls the die to determine who goes first.
You roll the die and you MUST move your piece that number of spaces even if it means losing gems! After you have moved you then place one of your cards from your hand onto the board to change the layout. This can be to your advantage or to sabotage another player.

Keep track of your scores with a notepad and pen to make it easier and once all players have played their cards and had an equal number of turns you count up the scores. The player with the highest score wins.

boardgame.name: Race To The Big Top
boardgame.description:
It's a race to the Big Top. The show must go on, but will you make it in time? The Tiger has escaped, the Strongman is picking on you, and a monkey just locked you in a cage. Walk the tightrope and maybe get fired out of a cannon.

On your turn, roll the dice and move. Ccllecting Rescue Cards to protect yourself from the Pitfalls along the way. Try to land on the Big Top spaces to collect Big Top cards which can help you along the way or may allow you to Challenge the other players. Try to land on the Peanut spaces to protect yourself from the other players playing Challenge cards. Be the first to reach the Big Top and WIN!
